learning_objective: Observe intellectual property rights and give appropriate attribution when creating or remixing programs.
topic: Kinetic, Potential, and Changes in Energy
question_str:
{
    "Question": "Alex has developed a program that calculates both potential and kinetic energy when given mass, height, velocity and gravitational constant. Recently, they found an open-source code that also calculates change in energy. Instead of writing his own code for calculating change in energy, Alex decides to use chunks of the open-source code in their program. What should Alex do to ensure they respect intellectual property rights?",
    "Answer1": "Alex can just copy the code and use it in their program without indicating where it came from.",
    "Answer2": "Alex should try to rewrite the code in a different way, so it does not look like they copied it.",
    "Answer3": "Alex needs to mention in their program that parts of their code are derived from the open-source code and provide a link to the original code.",
    "Answer4": "Since it is open-source, Alex doesn't need to do anything as they are free to use the code in any way they want.",
    "CorrectAnswer": "3",
    "Explanation": "Intellectual property rights should always be respected. Even if the code is open-source, it is professional decorum (and often required under the terms of use) to give proper attribution to the original creator or source."
}
